item.description:
(US, 1940) Director: Alfred Hitchcock. Screenplay by Robert E. Sherwood and Joan Harrison, based on the novel by Daphne du Maurier. Cast: Laurence Olivier, Joan Fontaine, George Sanders, Judith Anderson.

“Last night I dreamt I went to Manderley again...” Thanks to our generous donors, including Friends of Cinestudio, a new audience can enjoy the eerie opening line of Rebecca (and everything that follows) in a classic theater dedicated to cinema alone. As movie fans know, Rebecca was Alfred Hitchcock’s first movie made in the States, and it signals the start of a more personal expressiveness, along with his brilliant technical innovations. The young and naïve Joan Fontaine marries a brooding widower (Laurence Olivier), who brings her home to Manderley, a windswept Cornish estate. In over her depth, Fontaine is tormented by a fanatically loyal housekeeper (the great Judith Anderson), and the memory of Rebecca, Olivier’s first wife. Academy Award® for Best Picture. “A gorgeous treat from one of cinema’s masters.

group.name: Beyond the Multiplex: Hartford's Indie and Foreign Film fans

item.name: Alfred Hitchcock's Rebecca
